title: Alice Holt Forest Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Colin Smith / Alice Holt Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Alice Holt Forest. Track south of Alice Holt Lodge Research Station. The wood is mainly coniferous trees and sandy tracks.

images.title: Shazz / Shipwrights' Way 3, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Shipwrights Way long distance footpath in the Forest

images.title: Colin Smith / Track in Alice Holt Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Holly is growing by the bridleway through the mixed forest.

images.title: Martyn Pattison / Lodge Pond, Alice Holt Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lodge Pond. Some nice waterside trails in this tranquil area

images.title: don cload / Direction Sign at Alice Holt Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Direction Sign at the forest. This is in the car park close to the visitor centre which can be seen through the trees

images.title: Martyn Pattison / The visitor centre at Alice Holt forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: People sit outside on the tables at the visitor centre. This ancient forest is famous for its oak trees which once supplied timber for navy ships. Recently Alice Holt oak has been used to build a replica of Shakespeare's Globe theatre in London.

description: Explore the peaceful Alice Holt Forest on this pleasant circular route in Farnham . The trail makes use of National Cycle routes 224 and 22 which run through the forest. The route starts and finshes at Bentley rail station and follows the tracks through the forest, before returning along a lovely quiet country lane, giving splendid views of the surrounding Hampshire countryside. The path also passes Birdworld with its 26 acres of wildlife including Maribou Stork, Sunbirds, Penguins, Owls, Parrots, Waterfowl and flamingos. This trail is also suitable for walkers although you may wish to return to Bentley rail on one of the forest trails rather than along the country lanes. To extend your exercise you could head towards the worthy village of Tilford and visit Frensham Ponds where there's some fine waterside trails around the two large ponds. Just to the east there are more nice woodland trails in Bourne Woods , site of Ridley Scott's Robin Hood Film set from his 2010 film starring Russell Crowe.
